title: How to get things built (or finding someone who can)

lineItems.title: Introduce & assess yourself
lineItems.html:
Introduce yourself

  1. Name, Project
  2. Pick your preferred leadership roles beyond CEO: (CTO, CFO, Art Director, Marketing Manager, Product Manager, ?)
  3. If you could have any super power, what would it be?

Assess yourself

  • How confident do you feel about achieving your goals
  • How confident do you feel you can build your app on-time and with this budget?

lineItems.title: Picking a development methodology
lineItems.html:
Methodologies for the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)

  • Waterfall
  • DevOps / Agile
  • Rapid Application Development (RAD)

lineItems.title: Identify project dependencies
lineItems.html:
Where does your primary data come from?

  • End users?
  • You or your service providers?
  • Some company or goverment agency?
  • A crawler?

Do you need strong admin editorial tools / complex permissions?

Do you require a single search field over traditional navigation?

lineItems.title: Picking services and tools
lineItems.html:
Front-End Libraries

  • Web: React vs. Angular, Vue...?
  • Mobile: React Native vs. native platform SDKs
  • IoT: Node-Red, ... ?

Back-End Content Management Systems (CMS)

  • Drupal 8+ (php + mysql)
  • KeystoneJS (nodejs + mongo)
  • Java, Ruby, Python, .Net, ...?

Deployment

  • Heroku / Firebase (guarantees portability, requires external storage)
  • Google Cloud Platform / AWS (guarantees scalability)
  • GoDaddy / Ionos (cheap)

lineItems.html:
Searching your private network

  • Social media
  • University CS departments

Searching developers by online code forums

  • StackExchange networks (StackOverflow)
  • Github Issues
  • Leetcode

Upwork.com / TopTal.com / ?

  • Local
  • US
  • Americas
  • Global

lineItems.title: Screen Sharing
lineItems.html:
Review Github account history and repositories.

  • Does age / languages of repositories match up with claimed experience?
  • How often do they commit?
  • Make sure repos aren't just forks of other's work

Request debugging demonstation:

  • Do they use a modern IDE like JetBrains products or Eclipse / Visual Studio / ?
  • Do they use testing tools like Postman
  • Can they set runtime breakpoints in their code?

lineItems.title: Feature Requests
lineItems.html:
Github Issues, Jira, Trillo, Bugzilla, ...


Request Structure

  • Title
  • Description
  • Component / Label
  • Priority / Deadline
  • Assignee

Default Label Categories. Adding new ones: 

  • Design
  • Copywriting
  • Navigation
  • Form Submissions (on success)
  • Form Failures (error handling)
  • ?

lineItems.title: Bug Reporting
lineItems.html:
• Component: Flag the issue with all appropriate Labels
  • Title: How would you describe the bug in less than 60 characters? It should quickly and uniquely identify a bug report as well as explain the problem, not your suggested solution. Good: "Canceling a File Copy dialog crashes File Manager" Bad: "Software crashes" Bad: "Browser should work with my web site"
  • OS: On which operating system (OS) did you find it? (E.g. Linux, Windows, and Mac.) Example: "If you know the bug happens on more than one type of operating system, choose "All". If your OS isn't listed, choose Other".
  • Steps to Reproduce: Minimized, easy-to-follow steps that will trigger the bug. If they're necessary, make sure to include any special setup steps. A good example of this would look like the following:
    1) View any web page. (I used the default sample page, http://www.google.com/).
    2) Drag-select the page. Specifically, while holding down the mouse button, drag the mouse pointer downwards from any point in the browser's content region to the bottom of the browser's content region.
  • Actual Results: What the application did after performing the above steps. An example would be: The application crashed.
  • Expected Results: What the application should have done, were the bug not present. An example would be: The window should scroll downwards. Scrolled content should be selected. Or, at least, the application should not crash.
